frontmatter.title: Jekyll Tutorial: How to Build Your First Website
frontmatter.excerpt: Whether you‚Äôre looking to build your first ever website, or have been developing for a while but want a simpler way to...

pageContext.html:
Whether you‚Äôre looking to build your first ever website, or have been developing for a while but want a simpler way to manage your content and presentation, Jekyll could be a suitable option.

Jekyll is a static site generator (SSG), which means it takes content and page templates, and combines them to create static HTML and CSS which can be deployed. Jekyll itself is probably the most popular SSG out there.

SSGs have gained widespread adoption for a multitude of reasons. Compared to dynamic sites which use a full-stack CMS like Wordpress or are backed by a Node or Ruby server, they render much faster, offer greater security, cost less to run, and scale more easily. Really, a question you should be thinking about these days is, ‚ÄúDo I need to use anything other than a static site?‚Äù

How to Install Jekyll

Jekyll is written in Ruby, and so you‚Äôll need a Ruby development environment to use it. If you‚Äôre using MacOS, then Ruby is already included with the most recent versions of the OS.

You also need Xcode Command Line Tools which provides GCC and GNU Make. These are used to build ‚Äúnative extensions‚Äù for Ruby, where some parts of a package are written in C or C++. You can install them using:

xcode-select --install

You can check which version of Ruby you have installed using:

ruby -v

If you don‚Äôt have it, or are running an old version (anything below 2.3), then the easiest way to update it is using Homebrew. Once you‚Äôve installed Homebrew, run:

brew install ruby

Ruby ships with a package manager, RubyGems, which you can use to install programs (‚Äúgems‚Äù) written in Ruby. We‚Äôll use this firstly to install something called Bundler, which helps with dependency management for Ruby gems:

sudo gem install bundler

Now we‚Äôre ready to use RubyGems to install Jekyll itself:

sudo gem install jekyll

For other operating systems, the Jekyll website includes detailed installation and set-up guides to get you started.

How to Use Jekyll

Once you‚Äôve installed Jekyll, you can create a new project using the terminal. We‚Äôll also initialise git in the folder we create:

jekyll new jekyll-site
cd jekyll-site
git init

Jekyll comes with a development server which you can use to run your site locally once you‚Äôve built it.

bundle exec jekyll serve

In this command, bundle exec instructs Bundle to run the jekyll serve command (which actually fires up the development server) in the context of the current bundle. This means it uses the Gemfile in the current project directory, which describes gem dependencies required to execute Ruby code.

If you now navigate to http://127.0.0.1:4000/ in your browser, you‚Äôll see the Jekyll starter project up and running. Once the Jekyll server is running, you can make changes to the project and Jekyll will pick them up and rebuild automatically, so you don‚Äôt need to stop and restart the server.

With a completed site, you‚Äôd tell Jekyll to build the site and output static files to a directory. If you run:

bundle exec jekyll build

This will output your static site to the _site folder, ready to deploy. You should never manually put files in the _site folder.

Let‚Äôs take a moment to look at the structure of the starter project. It should look like this:

_config.yml is a file in YAML format which provides metadata for your site, including things like the title. Go ahead and make some changes. You will need to restart the server when you change this file in particular, so go ahead and do so to see your changes in browser. This file also specifies the Jekyll theme we‚Äôre using - more on this later.

index.md and about.md are the two pages of the website. When Jekyll builds your site, it looks for .md (Markdown) files, and compiles them into HTML based on layouts in the theme you are using. If you look at the top of about.md, you can see it specifies which layout should be used for the About page:

layout: page

Notice that about.md also includes another line which specifies a URL path for the page when it‚Äôs built:

permalink: /about/

This makes it accessible at http://localhost:4000/about/.

How to Post Content to Jekyll

You‚Äôll see that the starter site already has a blog post displayed on the homepage. This is being generated from a file in the _posts directory. You can create new files in this directory, and Jekyll will pick them up and build them.

To create a new post, add a new markdown file with the name formatted as YYYY-MM-DD-title.markdown. For example:

cd _posts
echo > 2018-09-17-my-first-post.markdown

Let‚Äôs add some content to it:

---
layout: post
title:  "This is my first Jekyll post!"
date:   2018-09-17
---

This is the first Jekyll post I have created.

Notice that in the browser, Jekyll constructs URLs for the posts based on the date. If you included a ‚Äúcategories‚Äù line at the top of the markdown file, as is the case in the default ‚ÄúWelcome to Jekyll!‚Äù post, these would also be used in the URL.

You can also place draft content in the _drafts folder. These files are named without a date but otherwise similar to your _posts content. Running jekyll serve with the ‚Äìdrafts parameter will include draft content in your site build.

In practice, unless your site is going to change very infrequently, you probably wouldn‚Äôt want to create posts yourself, What you‚Äôd be more likely to do is use a headless CMS, which would manage your content and provide markdown to Jekyll in the appropriate format. There are many choices to do this, and a good option might be a git-based CMS which would commit post content to the _posts folder as it‚Äôs written.

Jekyll Markdown Basics

So you now know how to create posts for Jekyll. But what‚Äôs with this Markdown format that they use?

There are two parts to the markdown files. The top section, between the triple hyphens, is referred to as ‚Äúfront matter‚Äù. This is essentially metadata about the post which Jekyll uses when building the site, and is in YAML format. We‚Äôve already talked about several of the front matter fields.

The second part of the files is the markdown itself. Markdown is fairly straightforward to write, with a few minor pieces of syntax to learn. Here are some of the key things you‚Äôll need to know:

Headings are denoted with # symbols, based on the level of the heading.

# This is a top-level (h1) heading.
## This is a second-level (h2) heading.

Generally your text will be formatted by the theme rather than the markdown, but there are a few modifications you can make for emphasis:

*Asterisks* or _underscores_ denote italic emphasis
**Double asterisks** or __double underscores__ denote bold emphasis
**These can be _combined_**
~~Double tildes~~ denote strikethrough.

Lists can be denoted by numbers:

1. First list item
2. Second list item

Or can be bulleted:

* First list item
* Second list item

Sub-lists are indented with two spaces.

Links can be embedded in a variety of ways, but most commonly are written inline:

This is an inline link to [Stackbit](http://stackbit.com).

Images, which you‚Äôll want to place in the site‚Äôs assets folder, can also be embedded inline:

![Photo of Simon](/assets/simon.jpg)

These should be enough to get you started writing posts. There‚Äôs more that Markdown can do, and an excellent source of reference for the full syntax is the Markdown Cheatsheet.

Jekyll Layouts

Great, so we can add new pages and posts to our Jekyll site. But the Markdown files we‚Äôve looked at only contain content. The other piece of the puzzle is templating to define the appearance of the pages when they‚Äôre built.

Jekyll layouts are stored in the _layouts folder, and use the Liquid template language which was developed by Shopify. The layout used by a particular post is defined in the front matter for the post, as we saw earlier. Templates take a .html extension and look something like this:

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <title>{{ page.title }}</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>{{ page.title }}</h1>
    <p>{{ content }}</p>
  </body>
</html>

When Jekyll builds a page with this template, content from the markdown file being parsed is injected into the HTML in place of the Liquid tags {{ page.title }} and {{ content }}.

As our templates begin to become more complex, we can also start to place re-usable code into the _includes folder. Partial templates in this folder can be used in your layouts via the {% include .html %} Liquid tag. There‚Äôs much more you can do with Liquid templates, and the official liquid documentation covers their capabilities in extensive detail.

So this gives us the ability to build HTML pages with our markdown. But they won‚Äôt look great right now. We need Jekyll to create some stylesheets for the pages. Jekyll provides build in support for Sass. If you create .scss files in a /css/ folder within your Jekyll project, it will automatically compile them to .css files when you build.

You can also include Sass partials in the _sass folder and reference them via @import in your /css/ Sass assets.

Pick Out a Jekyll Theme

You could build up the appearance of a site yourself, but Jekyll comes with support for 3rd party themes which you can use for the appearance of your site. Because Jekyll is widely used, there are many themes available to choose from.

Themes typically come with pre-built content for the assets, _layouts, _includes and _sass directories. - so essentially they‚Äôre providing styled layout templates for you. For some themes, you‚Äôll simply download a bundle and extract it to your project directory. One that we like is Massively.

Once you‚Äôve extracted the theme to your project directory, run:

bundle install

This will install any dependencies the theme requires.

You should check that none of the theme‚Äôs files conflict with alternatively-named files which already exist. For example, you probably have an empty index.md file, and Massively comes with an index.html. You want to remove index.md, otherwise it will override Massively‚Äôs file.

Now, fire up the Jekyll server and see the new theme in action.

You‚Äôll also find Jekyll themes which can be installed as a Ruby gem. In this case, the theme‚Äôs files are stored within the gem and hidden from you, rather than appearing in your project directory. The default theme Jekyll uses when you run jekyll new is Minima, but you‚Äôll notice its layouts are not visible in your folder structure.

To install a gem-based Jekyll theme, we need to add the theme to the project‚Äôs Gemfile (it‚Äôs usually best to start this with a new project rather than on top of another theme you‚Äôve manually installed):

gem ‚Äújekyll-athena"

Then direct your site to use the theme in config.yml:

theme: jekyll-athena

Finally, have Bundle install the theme:

bundle install

Once again, you can fire up the server and see the new theme in action.

You can also override a gem-based theme‚Äôs files by creating copies of its files in the appropriate project directory and modifying them. You can find out where the theme‚Äôs files are located by running bundle show with the theme name, such as:

bundle show jekyll-athena

Regardless of how you install the theme, once you‚Äôve done so, you can get to work tweaking it to your liking and authoring your markdown content, to get your first Jekyll site ready for the world.

sections.name: title
sections.title: Join The Team
sections.subtitle: Make building and maintaining modern websites easy.

column1.title: About Stackbit
column1.text: Websites are the building blocks of the internet and many millions of new ones are created every year. The way we create and engineer websites is changing thanks to the constant evolution of tools, best practices and needs. We're seeing websites being statically generated, served from CDNs, edited using Headless CMSs and wired up with a myriad of developer workflows. New ideas like the JAMstack, Serverless computing and GitOps enable us to create more performant and secure websites.

column2.title: Building The New Internet
column2.text: One side effect of new, raw technologies is that they can increase the level of expertise required to get the job done. We recognize this gap between the available technologies and the needs of professionals as the product gap. At Stackbit our mission is to solve this gap - We're creating technology, products and services to help professionals "Get Websites Done".

sections.name: banner
sections.title: Stackbit was founded in late 2018 by a team of serial entrepreneurs and is backed by top tier VCs. We maintain a small HQ in San-Francisco and our team is fully distributed around the world.
